body.#text: A genetic disorder that is sex-linked cannot also be ___________________.

feedback.#text: Incorrect. Sex-linked refers to disorders found on the X or Y chromosomes. These disorders can be either dominant or recessive.
Incorrect. Sex-linked refers to disorders found on the X or Y chromosomes. These disorders can be either dominant or recessive.
Correct. Sex-linked refers to disorders found on the X or Y chromosomes, whereas autosomal disorders are not found on the sex chromosomes.
Incorrect. Sex-linked refers to disorders found on the X or Y chromosomes. These disorders can be either dominant or recessive. Autosomal disorders are not found on the sex chromosomes.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: In humans, how many alleles of genes found on the X chromosome do male have?

feedback.#text: Incorrect. Males have an X chromosome
Correct. Males have only one X chromosome
Incorrect. Males have only one X chromosome
Incorrect. Males have only one X chromosome
You did not respond to this question.

p.#text: Use the following information to answer the next two questions.

#array.#text: In humans, the condition for normal blood clotting (H) is dominant to hemophilia (h). Suppose William, who has hemophilia, and Linda, who is a carrier for hemophilia, have a son, Mark. What is the probability that Mark will have this condition?

feedback.#text: Incorrect. From the information provided, we can determine William’s and Linda’s genotypes. William is hemophilic and must be XhY. Linda, a carrier, is heterozygous, so she must be XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of sons that are XHY and do not have the condition, and 50% that are XhY and do have the condition.

Incorrect. From the information provided, we can determine William’s and Linda’s genotypes. William is hemophilic and must be XhY. Linda, a carrier, is heterozygous, so she must be XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of sons that are XHY and do not have the condition, and 50% that are XhY and do have the condition.

Correct. From the information provided, we can determine William’s and Linda’s genotypes. William is hemophilic and must be XhY. Linda, a carrier, is heterozygous, so she must be XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of sons that are XHY and do not have the condition, and 50% that are XhY and do have the condition.

Incorrect. From the information provided, we can determine William’s and Linda’s genotypes. William is hemophilic and must be XhY. Linda, a carrier, is heterozygous, so she must be XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of sons that are XHY and do not have the condition, and 50% that are XhY and do have the condition.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: If William and Linda have a daughter, what is the probability that she will have this condition?

feedback.#text: Incorrect. We know William’s genotype is XhY, and Linda’s is XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of daughters that are XHXh and do not have the condition (but are carriers), and 50% that are XhXh and do have the condition.

Incorrect. We know William’s genotype is XhY, and Linda’s is XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of daughters that are XHXh and do not have the condition (but are carriers), and 50% that are XhXh and do have the condition.

Correct. We know William’s genotype is XhY, and Linda’s is XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of daughters that are XHXh and do not have the condition (but are carriers), and 50% that are XhXh and do have the condition.

Incorrect. We know William’s genotype is XhY, and Linda’s is XHXh. Crossing XhY and XHXh results in 50% of daughters that are XHXh and do not have the condition (but are carriers), and 50% that are XhXh and do have the condition.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: Nondisjunction in meiosis I results in

choice.#text: two cells missing a chromosome and two healthy cells.
two cells with an additional chromosome and two healthy cells
two cells missing a chromosome and two cells with an additional chromosome
one cell missing a chromosome, one cell with missing a chromosome and two healthy cells.

feedback.#text: Incorrect. This result is not possible.
Incorrect. This result is not possible
Correct. Meiosis I results in a homologous pair separating improperly.
Incorrect. This would be the result of nondisjunction in meiosis II.
You did not respond to this question.

#array.#text: According to the pedigree below, this trait is ____________________.

feedback.#text: Incorrect. The female on the bottom left row has the trait and neither of her parents has it. Therefore, the trait is recessive.
Correct. The female on the bottom left row has the trait and neither of her parents has it. Therefore, the trait is recessive.
Incorrect. This trait is not more common in males.
Incorrect. This trait is not more common in males.
You did not respond to this question.

#array.#text: What is the genotype of the unshaded individuals in the pedigree below?

feedback.#text: Incorrect. This trait is recessive because the female on the bottom left row has the trait and neither of her parents has it. Therefore, the unshaded (recessive) individuals are "aa".
Incorrect. This trait is recessive because the female on the bottom left row has the trait and neither of her parents has it. Therefore the unshaded (recessive) individuals are "aa".
Correct. This trait is recessive because the female on the bottom left row has the trait and neither of her parents has it. Therefore, the unshaded (recessive) individuals are "aa".
Incorrect. This trait is recessive because the female on the bottom left row has the trait and neither of her parents has it. Therefore, the unshaded (recessive) individuals are "aa".

body.#text: Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. If two heterozygous individuals breed, what is the chance that their offspring will develop Sickle cell anemia?

feedback.#text: Incorrect. A cross of Aa x Aa produces 25% aa (which will develop the disorder). It also produces 25% AA and 50% Aa (these will not develop the disorder).
Incorrect. A cross of Aa x Aa produces 25% aa (which will develop the disorder). It also produces 25% AA and 50% Aa (these will not develop the disorder).
Incorrect. A cross of Aa x Aa produces 25% aa (which will develop the disorder). It also produces 25% AA and 50% Aa (these will not develop the disorder).
Correct. A cross of Aa x Aa produces 25% aa (which will develop the disorder). It also produces 25% AA and 50% Aa (these will not develop the disorder).
You did not respond to this question.

#array.#text: Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder. A person with the disorder and a person that is a carrier mate. (

em.#text: A carrier has the allele for the trait but does not express it

p.#text: What is the chance that their offspring will develop sickle cell anemia?

feedback.#text: Incorrect. A cross of Aa x aa produces 50% aa (who will develop the disorder) and 50% Aa (who will not develop the disorder).
Incorrect. A cross of Aa x aa produces 50% aa (who will develop the disorder) and 50% Aa (who will not develop the disorder).
Correct. A cross of Aa x aa produces 50% aa (who will develop the disorder) and 50% Aa (who will not develop the disorder).
Incorrect. A cross of Aa x aa produces 50% aa (who will develop the disorder) and 50% Aa (who will not develop the disorder).
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: Hemophilia is a recessive disorder and is on the X chromosome. Hemophilia is _____________________.

choice.#text: found more often in males than females
found more often in females than males
equally common in males and females

feedback.#text: Correct. Males only have 1 X chromosome while females have 2, therefore males are more likely to develop the disorder.
Incorrect. Males only have 1 X chromosome while females have 2, therefore males are more likely to develop the disorder.
Incorrect. Males only have 1 X chromosome while females have 2, therefore males are more likely to develop the disorder.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: Genes on the X chromosome are called ______________.

feedback.#text: Incorrect. Autosomal genes are found on chromosomes other than the X or Y.
Incorrect. Somatic relates to cells other than gametes.
Correct. Sex-linked genes are found on the sex determining chromosomes.
Incorrect. Epistatic is when one gene affects the expression of another.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: The sex of the offspring is determined by _____________.

choice.#text: both the mother and the father

feedback.#text: Incorrect. The mother is XX and will only produce gametes with an X chromosome.
Correct. The father is XY and can either produce gametes with an X chromosome (which will be female) or gametes with a Y chromosome (which will be male).
Incorrect. The mother can only produce gametes with an X chromosome, the father will determine the sex of the offspring.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: Nondisjunction in meiosis II results in: ______________________

choice.#text: Two cells missing a chromosome and two healthy cells.
Two cells with an additional chromosome and two healthy cells.
Two cells missing a chromosome and two cells with an additional chromosome.
One cell missing a chromosome, one cell with missing a chromosome and two healthy cells.

feedback.#text: Incorrect. Nondisjunction produces a cell with an extra chromosome for every cell that is missing a chromosome because the chromosomes sorted incorrectly.
Incorrect. Nondisjunction produces a cell with a missing chromosome for every cell that has an extra chromosome because the chromosomes sorted incorrectly.
Incorrect. Nondisjunction in meiosis II will result in 2 normal cells.
Correct. Meiosis I occurred correctly, so 2 of the cells will have the correct number of chromosomes.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: Traits that are sex-linked and recessive are ________________________.

choice.#text: equally common in both males and females

feedback.#text: Correct. Males only have 1 X chromosome, while females have 2. So, recessive sex-linked traits tend to be more prominent in males.
Incorrect.
Incorrect.
You did not respond to this question.

body.#text: A gene that encodes an enzyme required for ribose synthesis is found on the X chromosome. Females that are heterozygous for the wild-type and defective mutant allele of this gene will show:

choice.#text: 50% of the enzyme activity in their cells, since one allele is inactive.
100% of the enzyme activity in their cells, since the X-chromosome with the inactive gene will be condensed.
50% of their cells will lack enzymatic activity, the other 50% will be active.
None of their cells will have the enzyme activity since the chromosome with the inactive allele will cause the other X-chromosome to become condensed.

feedback.#text: Incorrect. In any give cell only one of the X-chromosomes is condensed, thus a cell will show normal enzyme activity, or none at all.
Incorrect. The inactivation is random, thus a cell will show normal enzyme activity, or none at all.

Correct. The condensation of the X-chromosome is random, so the activity present in the cell will depend on which X-chromosome is condensed. Half the cells will express the normal gene, the other half the defective gene.
Incorrect. The inactivation is random, thus a cell will show normal enzyme activity, or none at all.
